div.p: This paper deals with a real-time weighted observerbased fault detection (FD) scheme for Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy systems. The essential idea is to develop a weighted diagnostic observer-based FD system to optimize the worst-case robustness and fault sensitivity simultaneously by using the information provided by each local system. To achieve an early detection of potential fault, the robustness issue is investigated in the L∞/L2 observer-based FD context. Meanwhile, the L-fault sensitivity condition is addressed to optimize the fault detectability. Using fuzzy Lyapunov functions, sufficient conditions on the FD system design are studied. Two examples are given in the end to show the efficiency of the proposed results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: O VER the past decades, the development on fault detection (FD) and fault-tolerant control approaches for complex nonlinear dynamic processes has attracted considerable attention from the application and research areas [1]- [4]. Among various FD studies, significant research effort has been made to the application of the well-established observer theory to deal with nonlinear FD issues [5]- [7]. For instance, sliding mode observer-based FD [8], adaptive observer-based FD [9], [10], diagnostic observer-based FD [11], [12] and fuzzy technique based FD [13] have been reported in the literature. In general, an integrated nonlinear observer-based FD system is composed by a nonlinear observer-based residual generator, a residual evaluator and a decision making unit including a threshold. Fault in complex systems could lead to hazardous consequences in both economic damage and physical security issues. This motivates the investigations on real-time process monitoring and fault detection schemes so as to detect and remove potential fault in the early stage [14], [15].

Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy dynamic model has been recognized as a powerful tool to describe the global behaviors of nonlinear systems [16], [17], for instance, Mars entry vehicles [18], robotic systems [19], etc. Motivated by this observation, intensive research effort has been dedicated to controller and filter synthesis for fuzzy systems [20], [21]. In recent years, some results have been proposed on the fault detection filter synthesis for fuzzy dynamic processes in the open literature [22]- [27]. It has been shown that most of these design approaches were formulated by finding a common quadratic Lyapunov function for a group of linear matrix inequalities, which tends to be conservative for many cases. This inherent conservatism has stimulated the development on the design schemes by means of more general types of Lyapunov functions, for instance, fuzzy/piecewise Lyapunov functions [28]- [30]. A nice feature of these advanced types of Lyapunov functions is that they are able to handle a larger set of fuzzy processes. On the other hand, it has been observed that the premise variables for some complex fuzzy processes are not always fully measurable in practice [31]. Reviewing the recent publications on fuzzy technique-based studies reveals that asynchronous fuzzy observer-based FD belongs definitely to the most challenging topics [32]. To the best of our knowledge, up to now, very few results have been reported on the diagnostic observer-based FD system design for fuzzy systems with unmeasurable premise variables.

False alarm rate (FAR) and fault detectability are two of the key indicators for evaluating the performance of a fault detection system. Most recently, studies on optimizing fault detectability under zero FAR have attracted intensive research interests for both linear and nonlinear processes [33]- [35]. Moreover, FD issues are also investigated to maximize the fault sensitivity under given robustness specification [12], [33]. On the other hand, considering that the local dynamic behaviors of complex nonlinear processes can be significantly different, the so-called gain-scheduling technique has been applied to optimize the fault detectability of the fuzzy FD systems [30]. Encouraged by this result, we are more interested in developing the fuzzy FD approach to attain the best fault sensitivity in the gain-scheduling manner.

In this paper, we develop a real-time weighted FD approach for fuzzy systems by means of non-synchronized diagnostic observers. To be specific, the weighted L ∞ /L 2 FD condition is developed to attain the robustness against known and unknown inputs, and the real-time fault detection. At the same time, the FD systems are so designed such that the L -fault sensitivity is optimized. The essential idea behind this FD approach consists in weighting the local residual generators in terms of different weighting matrices. As a result, the information on the local dynamic behavior of each local fuzzy system is used for the design procedure of FD systems.

The outline of the paper is given as follows. The preliminaries on fuzzy diagnostic observer-based FD approach and the problem to be addressed is given in Section II. The design approach of real-time weighted fuzzy FD systems with unmeasurable premise variables is addressed in Section III. In Section IV, two examples are used to show the effectiveness of the proposed approaches. Conclusions and future works are given in Section V.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORKS
div.p: The main objective of this paper is to address the integrated design of weighted diagnostic observer-based FD systems for T-S fuzzy processes. Based on fuzzy Lyapunov functions, sufficient conditions for guaranteeing the robustness and fault sensitivity simultaneously are studied for the fuzzy systems 1063-6706 (c) 2016 IEEE. To be specific, the robustness condition is addressed in the L ∞ /L 2 observer-based framework to attain the real-time detection of potential fault. At the same time, the worst case fault sensitivity condition (L -condition) is studied to optimize the fault detectability. Moreover, the basic idea behind this approach consists in optimizing the FD performance by taking into account the information of each local fuzzy system. The future work is dedicated to fault-tolerant control design approach with embedded fault diagnosis unit for nonlinear processes.
